subject: Re: [junit] When can you NOT use Mock objects?

messageBody:
Sometimes it is not possible or atleast not trivial to make a mock. In
particular with a final non-interfaced class. In this case it is not
possible to either write a mock based on the same interface or extend the
class.

There is a workaround to this, let's take java.net.URL as an example of a
class with no useful interface and that is final.

Simply don't use URL in your code. Always use your own interface say
'WebConnection'.

RealWebConnection is a simple adapter on the URL with passthrough methods
this is used everywhere a URL would be used.

Now you can write tests for any classes that use webconnection as you can
create a MockWebConnection.

---
There are other problems related to MockObject usage such as the singleton
pattern. However there *are* workarounds to all problems and I have seen no
situation where a test can not be written using MockObjects.

Regards,
Matt
